pageContext.description:
The landscape background extends over both interior wing panels, which each depict three female saints and their attributes: on the left panel Sts Dorothea, Agnes and Kunigunde, on the right Barbara, Ursula and Margaret. Although the figures are arranged in a group the saints appear isolated, unrelated to each other and the event taking place on the central panel. Common to all is the richness and variety of their attire. It is clear that Cranach's main interest lay here as the saints' robes seem to display the latest fashion in the Saxon court. 

[Görres, in Bonnet, Kopp-Schmitt, Görres 2010, 142]

metadata.title: Altarpiece with the Martyrdom of St Catharine: St Dorothea, St Agnes, St Kunigunde [left wing, recto]

pageContext.provenance:
- one of the first paintings, that Elector Friedrich III. the Wise commissioned from Lucas Cranach for the Wittenberg Schlosskirche 
- before 1586 the altarpiece was taken to Torgau, Schloss Hartenfels
- 1738 the altarpiece was taken to Dresden by the court painter Bonaventura Rossi (Vorrat der Gemäldegalerie)
- in the 18th century the panel was split. The panel was auctioned in 1797/1798 
- presumably in the collection of Heinrich Wilhelm Campe (Leipzig) as Hans Baldung Grien
- 1827 acquird by Maximilian Speck von Sternburg
- 1931 given on permanent loan to the Gemäldegalerie Dresden
- 1955 returned from Russia
- 1996 acquired by the Gemäldegalerie

[Exhib. Cat. Chemnitz 2005, 382]
pageContext.relatedWorks:
- Lucas Cranach the Elder, left side wing, exterior (Genoveva, Apollonia), lime wood, 120.5 x 63 cm, National Gallery London, Inv. No.: NG6511.1

- Lucas Cranach the Elder, right side wing, exterior (Christina, Ottilia), lime wood, 123 x 67 cm, National Gallery London, Inv. No.: NG6511.2

restorationSurveys.overallAnalysis:
In the 18th century the wing panels were sawn to create four separate panels

[Giebe, Schölzel 1996, 63]

Support:
- the panel has been trimmed on all four sides
- marks from a plane on the reverse
- cradle consisting of nine vertical and four cross-battens
- the joins are reinforced with wooden blocks
- reddish glaze on the reverse and the cradle

Painted surface:
- woodworm damage, particularly along the joins (open channels)
- retouches (joins, splits, irregularities in the wood)
- prominent craquelée with small paint lossses and retouches
- old, glossy varnish

[Schlegel 2003, 6][1]
[1][Schlegel, Schölzel, Exhib. Cat. Chemnitz 2005, 378]

tests.text:
- lime wood
- 0.26-0.4 cm thick (thinned)
- 9 horizontal planks
  
[Schlegel 2003, 6][1]
[1][Schlege, Exhib. Cat. Chemnitz 2005, 378]

The underdrawing, which was executed with a brush, reveals the artist’s struggles to finalize the composition and forms; linear contours are combined with a detailed drawing of the main features within the forms; radical changes were made in the painted version to the sightlines and the poses of the figures eg. the boy who was first shown in profile, the head of St Agnes, which has been altered as has the hairstyle of St Dorothea

[Schölzel, Exhib. Cat. Chemnitz 2005, 378]
